fields.description:
Crowd log is full of messages complaining about crowd not being able to remove a user from a group because the user was not found.

If you think a little bit about this, it makes no sense. Obviously if the user is does not exist he is no longer member of the group.

{code}

com.atlassian.crowd.exception.UserNotFoundException: User <#ccss - operations> does not exist
        at com.atlassian.crowd.dao.user.UserDAOHibernate.findByName(UserDAOHibernate.java:194)
        at com.atlassian.crowd.dao.user.UserDAOHibernate.findByName(UserDAOHibernate.java:50)
        at com.atlassian.crowd.directory.AbstractInternalDirectory.findUserByName(AbstractInternalDirectory.java:150)
        at com.atlassian.crowd.directory.AbstractInternalDirectory.removeUserFromGroup(AbstractInternalDirectory.java:849)
        at com.atlassian.crowd.directory.DbCachingRemoteChangeOperations.removeUserMembershipsForGroup(DbCachingRemoteChangeOperations.java:750)
        at sun.reflect.GeneratedMethodAccessor345.invoke(Unknown Source)
        at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:43)
        at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:606)
        at org.springframework.aop.support.AopUtils.invokeJoinpointUsingReflection(AopUtils.java:317)
        at org.springframework.aop.framework.ReflectiveMethodInvocation.invokeJoinpoint(ReflectiveMethodInvocation.java:183)
        at org.springframework.aop.framework.ReflectiveMethodInvocation.proceed(ReflectiveMethodInvocation.java:150)
        at org.springframework.transaction.interceptor.TransactionInterceptor$1.proceedWithInvocation(TransactionInterceptor.java:96)
        at org.springframework.transaction.interceptor.TransactionAspectSupport.invokeWithinTransaction(TransactionAspectSupport.java:260)
        at org.springframework.transaction.interceptor.TransactionInterceptor.invoke(TransactionInterceptor.java:94)
        at org.springframework.aop.framework.ReflectiveMethodInvocation.proceed(ReflectiveMethodInvocation.java:172)
        at org.springframework.aop.framework.JdkDynamicAopProxy.invoke(JdkDynamicAopProxy.java:204)
        at com.atlassian.crowd.directory.$Proxy372.removeUserMembershipsForGroup(Unknown Source)
        at com.atlassian.crowd.directory.DirectoryCacheImplUsingChangeOperations.syncUserMembersForGroup(DirectoryCacheImplUsingChangeOperations.java:119)
{code}

This is currently logged as INFO + Exception trace, so it fills our logs with bogus information.

The expected behavior would be to ignore this, obviously the user is removed, even if we are able to find it.

Now, let me explain the setup a little bit, to understand it better. 
* We are using nested groups
* Not all LDAP groups are editable by crowd, in fact only just few of them are.
* These two are both groups.
* We do map few groups as users (altering the crowd LDAP filters), this allows us to view them as users in jira, and to attach tickets to them.

I would expect to see this kind of error with such virtual-user, but that's not the case, in both cases these are just LDAP groups that are not treated separately.
fields.summary: DbCachingRemoteChangeOperations] Could not remove user [xxx] from group [yyy]. User was not found.

fields.description:
h1. Background

For CWD-3756, the concept of a recovery mode was added to Crowd core so that administrators could more easily recover administrator access when they locked themselves out of Crowd.

However, this was only implemented as a possible option in Crowd's core so that each product which embeds Crowd (Confluence, JIRA, Stash, and Crowd itself) could choose whether to enable it or not.

Currently, Crowd itself does not allow this recovery mode to be enabled.

h1. Feature

Allow recovery mode in Crowd to be enabled so that customers have an easier recovery option than the long procedure detailed in [Restoring Passwords To Recover Admin User Rights|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWDKB/Restoring+Passwords+To+Recover+Admin+User+Rights].

We should make it clear in Crowd's UI when recovery mode is enabled.
fields.summary: Support Recovery Mode in Crowd server

fields.description:
Currently, there is no way to come up with a list of authentication history for the users in Crowd.

This authentication history would be useful for a centralized view on which user logged in to which application at which time and whether or not these login attempts where successful. 

Such an authentication list would be useful to identify for example password attacks on certain users and so on.
fields.summary: Provide a list of authentication history

fields.description:
Since CWD-3796 , Crowd has two membership aggregation semantics. Crowd should offer a UI option to let admins choose which semantics they prefer to use for each application that connects to Crowd.

This also involves choosing the appropriate default value for:
* Existing installations
* New installations
fields.summary: As an admin, I want to choose the membership aggregation semantics I want for each application

fields.description: The Soy Template Renderer requires {{commons-beanutils}}. This has not been provided in Horde.
fields.summary: Horde missing dependency on commons-beanutils

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian Update - 8 June 2020|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3c78b5|titleBGColor=#3c78b5|bgColor=#e7f4fa}
Hello everyone,

We have recently reviewed this issue and the overall interest in the problem. As the issue hasn't collect votes, watchers, comments, or support cases from many customers during its lifetime, it's very low on our priority list, and will not be fixed in the foreseeable future. That's why we've decided to resolve it as *Timed Out*.

Although we're aware the issue is still important to those of you who were involved in the conversations around it, we want to be clear in managing your expectations. The Crowd team is focusing on issues that have broad impact and high value, reflected by the number of comments, votes, support cases, and customers interested. Please consult the [Atlassian Bugfix Policy|https://confluence.atlassian.com/support/atlassian-server-bug-fix-policy-201294573.html] for more details.

We understand how disappointing this decision may be, but we hope you'll appreciate our transparent approach and communication.

Atlassian will continue to watch this issue for further updates, so please feel free to share your thoughts in the comments.

Thank you,

Crowd Team
{panel}
 

MySQL and SQLServer discard trailing spaces for VARCHAR2 equivalence calculations so if two Crowd users in the same directory have user_names that differ only by trailing spaces then a uniqueness constraint violation will be raised.

The only workarounds at present are to fix the upstream directory attribute for the users (e.g. sAMAAccountName) or to switch to Oracle or Postgres.
fields.summary: UQ violations if lower_user_name differs only by trailing spaces (MySQL and SQLServer)

fields.description: We're already making extensive use of Guava's Preconditions, so there's not much reason for Crowd to have its own {{Assert}} class. Delete it and replace all use with Preconditions.
fields.summary: Delete Crowd-specific 'Assert' utility class

fields.description:
h1. Context
In Crowd 2.7.0, we had an issue with Crowd generating invalid XML documents due to binary data getting synced to the Crowd cache as the user's external id; we fixed this in 2.7.1 by not skipping syncing any attributes which are not representable in XML to the Crowd LDAP cache (specifically, in CWD-3748).

h1. Problem
Unfortunately, Novell eDirectory's GUID attribute (which is the default "User Unique Identifier Attribute" in Crowd) is [defined to be|http://www.novell.com/documentation/developer/ndslib/schm_enu/data/sdk1198.html] of type [Octet String|http://www.novell.com/documentation/developer/ndslib/schm_enu/data/sdk5652.html], so that attribute often has invalid-for-xml characters and hence is often not sync'd to Crowd's cache.

h1. Consequence

User renames will not be detected for any user whose GUID attribute is not XML safe.

Safety is determined according to {{com.atlassian.crowd.directory.ldap.util.XmlValidator#isSafe}}. More specifically, the GUID attribute value is safe and will not be skipped if every character meets the condition below:
{code}
                (c == 0x09 || c == 0x0A || c == 0x0D
                || (c >= 0x20 && c <= 0xD7FF)
                || (c >= 0xE000 && c <= 0xFFFD)
                || (c >= 0x10000 && c <= 0x10FFFF))
{code}
(e.g. 0x09 represents a valid xml character, 0x0B does not)
fields.summary: User renames are often not detected in Novell eDirectory because Crowd does not handle arbitrary attribute values

fields.description:
Some directories should allow very fast counting of elements inside them. Crowd should make this functionality avaliable via its api.

For example, in the basic case you can get every membership in a directory and count it manually in code. However, for some directories you should be able to directly ask the question to the directory and get the answer back in much less time. We should revert to the naive implimentation in the common case and speed up counting operations where we can.
fields.summary: Provide membership counting operations for the directories.

fields.description:
The basic authentication proposed by Crowd becomes to be outdated...

OAuth or SAMLv2 are good candidates to delegate the authentication to an external authentication mechanism.

Within my organisation, we have implemented an SSO based on CAS and it is exposed via OAuth or SAMLv2 mechanism.

Please do investigation in this area, it become to be critic and more difficult to justify the usage of the basic auth...
fields.summary: Delegate the crowd user authentication to an external authentication mechanism

fields.description:
Requests authenticating to Crowd's REST API will create a session. If clients use the same session cookie for subsequent requests then they can avoid reauthenticating, which may save time. However, as the only value of these sessions is for performance, there's no reason for the sessions to be long lived.

Reduce the timeout to a minute. After that long, the cost of reauthenticating is negligible.

At the same time, remove the code to delete Crowd sessions when the HttpSessions expire. They'll expire around the same time, which is good enough for them to provide indicative state.
fields.summary: Use a shorter timeout for the REST API's application sessions

fields.description:
Partially revert the change in CWD-3522 that used the reader/writer lock to distinguish between reading and writing operations.

The lock was intended to distinguish between use of the underlying token store ("reading") and switching between implementations ('writing"). Return to that behaviour and improve the documentation in the class.
fields.summary: Revert locking change to SwitchableTokenManagerImpl
Reduce number of redundant calls through DirectoryManager in ApplicationServiceGeneric

fields.description:
Further changes to the build process mean that Crowd builds from atlassian-crowd-2.8.0-OD-12 onwards have an empty {{crowd-plugin-test-resources}}, preventing starting a Crowd using that version through AMPS.

As a workaround, stick to an earlier {{crowd-plugin-test-resources}}; Crowd's upgrade tasks will run, so there shouldn't be any compatibility concerns.
fields.summary: crowd-plugin-test-resources broken again

fields.description:
When attempting to replace Crowd Internal Directory mapped to Crowd Application with LDAP Connector Directory, there's a possibility of accidentally removing all user permission at once if no group is mapped at Crowd Application.

h6. Steps to reproduce
# Ensure that Internal Crowd Administrator exists under 'crowd-administrators' group
# Create External Crowd Directory (LDAP Connector)
# Create External Directory's Crowd User to be designated as new Admin later
# Create External Directory's Crowd group 'crowd-administrators'
# Go to {{Applications >> Crowd}}
# At Directories tab, set the External Crowd Directory to the first position (Set Allow All to Authenticate: True)
# Login as the External Directory's Crowd User
# Go to {{Applications >> Crowd}}
# At Directories tab, remove Crowd Internal Directory

All of sudden, the user won't have permission to login Crowd. The existing internal Crowd Administrator won't be able to login to Crowd as well.

h6. Workaround
- Before attempting to replace Crowd Internal Directory, right after Step 6, add 'crowd-administrators' group (External Directory's) to the mapping
- If no user can't login at all, use the guide to [Restoring Passwords To Recover Admin User Rights|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWDKB/Restoring+Passwords+To+Recover+Admin+User+Rights]
fields.summary: Crowd Application Needs to Have at Least One Group Mapped Otherwise All Users Unable to Login

fields.description:
HtmlUnit and JWebUnit have both made new releases (2.14 and 3.2 respectively).

Picking up the upgrade has one issue; {{GzipFilterOptionTest}} now fails because the response seems to be being transparently decompressed. Assuming this is the case, the upgrade will need to override this decompression or find some way to confirm that it's taken place.
fields.summary: Upgrade HtmlUnit and JWebUnit

fields.description:
For some scenarios in which we know that all the updates to the remote directory happen through Crowd, it may be convenient to completely disable "downstream" synchronisation.

Currently it is possible to change the synchronisation interval in Crowd and set it to a very large value, but it would be better to prevent synchronisation from happening at all for a given directory.
fields.summary: As a sysadmin, I want to completely disable synchronisation for a cached LDAP connector directory

fields.summary: Installation fails due to unavailability of key plugins.

fields.description: This requires upgrading AMPS to pick up [AMPS-1029|https://ecosystem.atlassian.net/browse/AMPS-1029].
fields.summary: Allow Crowd to build with Maven 3.1 or greater

fields.description:
This was tested using [CROWD Apache Connector 1.3|https://studio.plugins.atlassian.com/source/browse/~tarball=zip/CWDAPACHE/branches/1.x/RPMS/RPMS.zip], worked perfectly till 2.7.0 but stops working after upgrade to 2.7.1.

A rollback to 2.7.0 fixes this.

Error on Logs:
{quote}
SOAP service fault for method: authenticateApplication
{quote}

Steps to reproduce:

# Deploy CROWD 2.7.0

fields.description:
For about four years we have been running a script to keep our Crowd groups memberships and user attributes in sync with our LDAP directory.  We discovered after upgrading Crowd on our dev and test apps that our script no longer works.  We have narrowed the problem down to (at a minimum) the inability to authenticate.  Here are two Python examples that illustrate the behavior.

Using Crowd 2.7.0:
{noformat}
ActivePython 2.6.5.14 (ActiveState Software Inc.) based on
Python 2.6.5 (r265:79063, Jul  4 2010, 21:05:58) [MSC v.1500 32 bit (Intel)] on win32
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import suds.client
>>> url_wsdl_prd_fixed = "file:///D:/dryan/SE/SS/Crowd/2.7.1/crowd_ssi-crowd-prd_2.7.0_fixed.wsdl.xml"
>>> c = suds.client.Client(url_wsdl_prd_fixed)
>>> auth_context = c.factory.create("ns1:ApplicationAuthenticationContext")
>>> auth_context.name = "ssp-sso-apps-prd"
>>> auth_context.credential.credential = "<password>"
>>> token = c.service.authenticateApplication(auth_context)
>>> token
(AuthenticatedToken){
   name = "ssp-sso-apps-prd"
   token = "BQw0rYa0zhf0j0ttVOnyWA00"
 }
{noformat}

Using Crowd 2.7.1:
{noformat}
ActivePython 2.6.5.14 (ActiveState Software Inc.) based on
Python 2.6.5 (r265:79063, Jul  4 2010, 21:05:58) [MSC v.1500 32 bit (Intel)] on win32
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.

>>> url_wsdl_tst_fixed = "file:///D:/dryan/SE/SS/Crowd/2.7.1/crowd_ssi-crowd-tst_2.7.0_fixed.wsdl.xml"
>>> c = suds.client.Client(url_wsdl_tst_fixed)
>>> auth_context = c.factory.create("ns1:ApplicationAuthenticationContext")
>>> auth_context.name = "ssp-sso-apps-tst"
>>> auth_context.credential.credential = "<password>"
>>> token = c.service.authenticateApplication(auth_context)
No handlers could be found for logger "suds.client"
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "C:\Applications\Python26\lib\site-packages\suds-0.3.9-py2.6.egg\suds\client.py", line 539, in __call__
    return client.invoke(args, kwargs)
  File "C:\Applications\Python26\lib\site-packages\suds-0.3.9-py2.6.egg\suds\client.py", line 598, in invoke
    result = self.send(msg)
  File "C:\Applications\Python26\lib\site-packages\suds-0.3.9-py2.6.egg\suds\client.py", line 633, in send
    result = self.failed(binding, e)
  File "C:\Applications\Python26\lib\site-packages\suds-0.3.9-py2.6.egg\suds\client.py", line 684, in failed
    r, p = binding.get_fault(reply)
  File "C:\Applications\Python26\lib\site-packages\suds-0.3.9-py2.6.egg\suds\bindings\binding.py", line 238, in get_fault
    raise WebFault(p, faultroot)
suds.WebFault: Server raised fault: 'Couldn't set property {http://authentication.integration.crowd.atlassian.com}credential on com.atlassian.crowd.integration.authentication.Appli
cationAuthenticationContext@2cf8aa09[name=<null>,credential=<null>,validationFactors=<null>]. null'
{noformat}

We tried taking a fresh 2.7.1 WSDL from http://ssi-crowd-tst.ptcnet.ptc.com:8095/crowd/services/SecurityServer?wsdl and applying the fixes referenced in https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CWD-159 but no luck.

Before we invest in a development effort to use Crowd's newer REST API instead of the SOAP API, we wanted to see if either this a truly a bug in the new Crowd version or whether there is some change we could make on our side to get our script to work.

fields.description:
The {{DirectoryManager}} provides a method {{searchUsers()}} which can only return a {{List}} of {{User}} or {{String}} (username). It also provides the methods {{findUserWithAttributesByName()}} and {{findUserWithAttributesByExternalId()}}, which retrieve one {{UserWithAttributes}}.

It would be nice to expand {{searchUsers()}} to be able to return {{UserWithAttributes}} too so that consumes do not have to first {{searchUsers()}}, only to then call {{findUserWithAttributesByX()}} {{n}} times.

fields.description:
{{crowd.properties}}, {{jdbc.properties}} and {{crowdid.approval-whitelist}} are read from the OpenID Server's classpath at runtime. Configuration changes require modifying something in the classpath, which may be read-only storage.

Add a {{crowd.openid.home}} system property which points to a directory containing Crowd OpenID Server's configuration files, which can be in an arbitrary user-specified location.

Old behaviour will be maintained by falling back to the existing classpath configurations if a user configuration is not supplied.

Crowd Team

fields.description:
In order to improve adoption and user interaction (particularly in multi language instances), it would be great to be able to display a more user friendly version of the display name.

For example, consider a user with a Japanese name who works with English and Japanese native speakers. This user has the option of entering his display name in English (_romaji_) or using Japanese characters (_kanamoji_) - but runs the risk of his name being incomprehensible to someone who isn't a native reader / speaker of the language he chooses.

The improvement would be to adjust the user profile to allow multiple display names, accompanied by a language flag to align with the viewer's chosen language.

In this way, users who do not speak Japanese would be able to at least see that "Kengo Ohsaki" has posted something, rather than 大崎 健吾 - which may not be legible to them.
fields.summary: Improving Display Names in different languages

fields.description:
Microsoft Active Directory escapes all trailing spaces in the DN components (not just the last one), which causes the spring-ldap 1.3 to fail. This breaks the directory sync from Active Directory that includes 'bad' DNs  

For example:

{noformat}
 import org.springframework.ldap.core.DistinguishedName
 val good = "CN=foo \\ ,DC=example,DC=com"
 val bad =  "CB=foo\\ \\ ,DC=example,DC=com"
 new DistinguishedName(good) // works
 new DistinguishedName(bad)  // throws an exception
{noformat}

See comments for example stack trace.
fields.summary: Crowd fails to parse AD DNs with more than one trailing spaces

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When there are multiple directories and membership aggregation is disabled for an applicatoin, group membership queries require an {{isCanonical}} check on each user. In order to do this {{isCanonical}} finds the user by name in order to shallow the user. This results in n+1 queries to the database. This can cause massive performance issues when the host application (in this case Stash) when calculating licensed user counts.

h3. Steps to Reproduce

It is not entirely clear at this point how to accurately replicate the problem. It involves configuring nested groups and multiple user directories, then using the application such that it retrieves user groups.

h3. Expected Results

Crowd retrieves nested groups with minimal performance impact.

h3. Actual Results

There is a notable performance impact on the system and it presents with symptoms of performance problems.

h2. Verification

Check for the presence of multiple threads utilising {{com.atlassian.crowd.manager.application.ApplicationServiceGeneric.isCanonical}} and/or {{com.atlassian.crowd.manager.application.ApplicationServiceGeneric.searchNestedGroupRelationships}}. For example from JIRA:

{noformat}
"http-bio-8080-exec-12889" daemon prio=10 tid=0x00007f9e7cb26800 nid=0xa4a runnable [0x00007f9e3125e000]
   java.lang.Thread.State: RUNNABLE
	at java.util.HashMap$HashIterator.nextEntry(Unknown Source)
	at java.util.HashMap$KeyIterator.next(Unknown Source)
	at java.util.AbstractCollection.addAll(Unknown Source)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.model.application.DirectoryMapping.<init>(DirectoryMapping.java:70)
	at com.atlassian.jira.crowd.embedded.ofbiz.OfBizApplication$1.apply(OfBizApplication.java:71)
	at com.atlassian.jira.crowd.embedded.ofbiz.OfBizApplication$1.apply(OfBizApplication.java:68)
	at com.google.common.collect.Lists$TransformingRandomAccessList.get(Lists.java:451)
	at java.util.AbstractList$Itr.next(Unknown Source)
	at com.google.common.collect.Iterators$8.next(Iterators.java:781)
	at com.google.common.collect.Iterators$7.computeNext(Iterators.java:644)
	at com.google.common.collect.AbstractIterator.tryToComputeNext(AbstractIterator.java:141)
	at com.google.common.collect.AbstractIterator.hasNext(AbstractIterator.java:136)
	at com.google.common.collect.Iterators.getNext(Iterators.java:860)
	at com.google.common.collect.Iterables.getFirst(Iterables.java:759)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.manager.application.ApplicationServiceGeneric.isCanonical(ApplicationServiceGeneric.java:1638)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.manager.application.ApplicationServiceGeneric$1.apply(ApplicationServiceGeneric.java:1587)
	at com.google.common.collect.Iterators$7.computeNext(Iterators.java:645)
	at com.google.common.collect.AbstractIterator.tryToComputeNext(AbstractIterator.java:141)
	at com.google.common.collect.AbstractIterator.hasNext(AbstractIterator.java:136)
	at com.google.common.collect.Iterables$10$1.hasNext(Iterables.java:884)
	at com.google.common.collect.Lists.newArrayList(Lists.java:138)
	at com.google.common.collect.Lists.newArrayList(Lists.java:119)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.manager.application.AggregatorImpl.constrainResults(ResultsAggregator.java:174)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.manager.application.ApplicationServiceGeneric.searchNestedGroupRelationships(ApplicationServiceGeneric.java:1582)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.embedded.core.CrowdServiceImpl.searchNestedGroupRelationships(CrowdServiceImpl.java:238)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.embedded.core.CrowdServiceImpl.search(CrowdServiceImpl.java:158)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.embedded.core.DelegatingCrowdService.search(DelegatingCrowdService.java:60)
	at com.atlassian.crowd.embedded.core.FilteredCrowdServiceImpl.search(FilteredCrowdServiceImpl.java:143)
	at com.atlassian.jira.security.groups.DefaultGroupManager.getUsersInGroup(DefaultGroupManager.java:107)
	at com.atlassian.jira.security.roles.actor.GroupRoleActorFactory$GroupRoleActor.getUsers(GroupRoleActorFactory.java:79)
	at com.atlassian.jira.security.roles.DefaultRoleActorsImpl.getUsers(DefaultRoleActorsImpl.java:51)
	at com.atlassian.jira.security.roles.CachingProjectRoleAndActorStore$CachedRoleActors.getUsers(CachingProjectRoleAndActorStore.java:415)
	at com.atlassian.jira.notification.type.ProjectRoleSecurityAndNotificationType.getUsersFromRole(ProjectRoleSecurityAndNotificationType.java:235)
	at com.atlassian.jira.notification.type.ProjectRoleSecurityAndNotificationType.getUsers(ProjectRoleSecurityAndNotificationType.java:138)
	at com.atlassian.jira.scheme.AbstractSchemeManager.getUsers(AbstractSchemeManager.java:819)
	at com.atlassian.jira.permission.WorkflowBasedPermissionSchemeManager.getUsers(WorkflowBasedPermissionSchemeManager.java:73)
	at com.atlassian.jira.bc.user.search.DefaultAssigneeService$AssignableUsers.findAllAsSet(DefaultAssigneeService.java:428)
	at com.atlassian.jira.bc.user.search.DefaultAssigneeService$AssignableUsers.findAll(DefaultAssigneeService.java:423)
	at com.atlassian.jira.bc.user.search.DefaultAssigneeService.getSuggestedAssignees(DefaultAssigneeService.java:70)
	at com.atlassian.jira.issue.fields.Assignees.optionsForFrotherControl(Assignees.java:70)
	at com.atlassian.jira.issue.fields.AssigneeSystemField.getEditHtml(AssigneeSystemField.java:168)
	at com.atlassian.jira.issue.fields.screen.AbstractFieldScreenLayoutItem.getEditHtml(AbstractFieldScreenLayoutItem.java:78)
	at com.atlassian.jira.issue.fields.screen.FieldScreenRenderLayoutItemImpl.getEditHtml(FieldScreenRenderLayoutItemImpl.java:62)
	at com.atlassian.jira.issue.fields.rest.FieldHtmlFactoryImpl.getEditFields(FieldHtmlFactoryImpl.java:151)
	at sun.reflect.GeneratedMethodAccessor1026.invoke(Unknown Source)
{noformat}

h3. Notes

In JIRA, this can also cause performance problems. For example, some user actions in JIRA like {{com.atlassian.jira.components.issueeditor.action.AjaxIssueEditAction.doDefault}} and {{com.atlassian.jira.issue.fields.screen.FieldScreenRenderLayoutItemImpl.getEditHtml}}, there are many) require JIRA to calculate the permissions, which involves calling {{com.atlassian.jira.security.groups.DefaultGroupManager.getUsersInGroup}}. JIRA delegates this operation to {{ApplicationServiceGeneric.searchNestedGroupRelationships}} in its embedded Crowd. Embedded Crowd is dependent on these classes from Crowd. This can be an expensive calculation which increases with the number of users. Unfortunately the loop inside that method causes many queries to the database, *many of them to fetch the directory mappings which are not cached*.
fields.summary: ApplicationServiceGeneric#searchNestedGroupRelationships performs n+1 queries in order to shadow users

fields.description:
During our migration from crowd 2.3.2 to 2.7.1 we discovered several issues.
During the import of previous exported xml backup from our 2.3.2 instance crowd becomes unresponsive.
We repeated our import several times and were finally able to get crowd running on 2.7.1.

After we switched our application to the new crowd instance, crowd becomes unresponsive again. At this point a restart of the system didn´t help. During the service start we saw many "broken pipe" and some "javax.ws.rs.WebApplicationException: javax.xml.bind.UnmarshalException" which leads us to #CWD-3772 and related tickets.

After we disabled the database session cache our crowd instance seems to work, but an uneasy feeling has left - a flawless upgrade feels other.

Because some of our crowd connected services are able to register users - we could not switch back without possible loose of user data.

I have attached catalina.out logfile. There you can find all exceptions to the described issues.
fields.summary: Upgrade from 2.3.2 to 2.7.1

fields.description:
Currently there is not possible to filter groups for application.
One example where this may be useful: when using nested groups. I want to use group1 to give access to confluence space.  But group1 has subgroup group2 where user belongs. So in order to authenticate with confluence I have to pull to crowd both group1 and group2 and add them to confluence application groups list in Crowd. But now administrator can see 2 groups in confluence: group1 and group2 and that may be question fro another administrator who does not know which group he/she should select. So It would be useful to have a feature where crowd administrator can select which groups confluence application is allowed to see.
fields.summary: filter groups for application

fields.description:
Crowd should amalgamate all group memberships for the same username across multiple directories. This works when querying the members of a group, but not when querying the group memberships of a user.

This works (pseudo-code):
crowdGroup.getUsers();

This does not:
crowdUser.getGroups();

Here's the offending REST endpoint:
localhost:4990/crowd/rest/usermanagement/1/user/group/direct?username=user1&start-index=0&max-results=-1

What this can mean in downstream applications is that all groups are amalgamated when a user logs in to Confluence, but when they log in to the admin console, they only get the memberships from the top directory in Crowd. This has caused problems for users where their confluence-administrators and jira-administrators groups are in the second place directory, and logging in to the admin console means they lose these groups and authentication fails.
fields.summary: Group amalgamation behaviour is inconsistent in Crowd

fields.description:
After recently upgrading our Crowd server (due to a duplicate key issue on authentication tokens, unrelated to this issue) the openidserver fails to service any requests.

We use the openidserver to authenticate our local developers for access to the CMS backends the company is building.

After the upgrade, the end-user who's trying to authenticate's browser is presented with a download of "application/xrds+xml" file "op", presumably the server's Yadis doc ( located at https://crowd.ourcompany.com/openidserver/op ) which AFAIK shouldn't be served to the user anyway.

After some debugging we tried the shipped openidclient, which fails all calls as well, stating:

{code}
Authentication Failed: Could not recieve authentication response from your OpenID provider. Contact your OpenID server's administrator.
{code}

The logs reveal why this is failing:

fields.description:
Active Directory provides the account-expires attribute (http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/ms675098%28v=vs.85%29.aspx). At the moment, there is no way to filter out 'expired' users in Crowd, because they aren't counted as disabled. 

The difference between expired and disabled is discussed here: http://social.technet.microsoft.com/Forums/windowsserver/en-US/365f6975-b5b8-4802-854e-b11ef75eb8f9/difference-between-account-types?forum=winservergen
fields.summary: Allow users from AD to be filtered on the accountExpires attribute

fields.description: Currently, if the user import fails halfway, Crowd will keep any user or group memberships it managed to import in the directory, despite the error. This leaves a directory in an "unstable" state. We need to have the ability to rollback the transaction, to the state prior to the import.
fields.summary: Ability to rollback to previous state, if User Import fails

Would be nice to centralize it on Crowd or for such application in order to  allow to reject group changes (as well as user additions or deletions) that do not come directly from Crowd.

fields.description:
At the moment our Crowd setup is linked to our AD and to Google Apps (for mail).  In the AD, all users have their corporate email address as main email address.  As a result, all users in Crowd also have that email address.

Now, a problem arises if a user resets his/her password, because the password email will be send to the corporate, for which he/she needs the Crowd credentials (because for email GMail is linked to Crowd SSO).

Is there any suggestion how to break this cycle?  Possibly support an alternative email address in the sync or allow the user to add an additional email address on first login?
fields.summary: Provide a way to reset passwords when the users' email accounts are protected by the same Crowd instance

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian Update - 8 June 2020|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3c78b5|titleBGColor=#3c78b5|bgColor=#e7f4fa}
Hello everyone,

We have recently reviewed this issue and the overall interest in the problem. As the issue hasn't collect votes, watchers, comments, or support cases from many customers during its lifetime, it's very low on our priority list, and will not be fixed in the foreseeable future. That's why we've decided to resolve it as *Timed Out*.

Although we're aware the issue is still important to those of you who were involved in the conversations around it, we want to be clear in managing your expectations. The Crowd team is focusing on issues that have broad impact and high value, reflected by the number of comments, votes, support cases, and customers interested. Please consult the [Atlassian Bugfix Policy|https://confluence.atlassian.com/support/atlassian-server-bug-fix-policy-201294573.html] for more details.

We understand how disappointing this decision may be, but we hope you'll appreciate our transparent approach and communication.

Atlassian will continue to watch this issue for further updates, so please feel free to share your thoughts in the comments.

Thank you,

Crowd Team
{panel}
 

While using an openldap backend to manage JIRA users, it sticks to use JIRA bind DN to perform the "Change Password" task rather than the authenticated DN of current logined user.

For some security reasons, the JIRA bind DN is granted limited privileges (such as authenticate, and reading specified fields of a directory) just for binding purpose. Under commonly crics, the user has the write privileges to his/her "userPassword" attribute in the directory. So JIRA should provide an option to use the authenticated user's DN to bind the directory while performing "Change Password".
fields.summary: Using User's Authenticated DN to perform "Change Password" in LDAP

fields.description:
From JRA-27353

Steps to reproduce:

1. install JIRA
2. setup LDAP directory - create test data (see below)
3. add LDAP directory in JIRA configuration with option "Enable Nested Groups" enabled
4. synchronize data
5. change name of "sub_group" to "Sub_group" and update uniqueMember parameter of parent_group to match changed name
6. synchronize data again - here crowd should fail on inserting data into database (CWD_MEMBERSHIP table)

I was able to reproduce it with HSQL and PostgreSQL.

Test data - two groups with relation:

    parent_group, uniqueMember= {sub_group}
    sub_group

LDIF export of my test data (I've configured LDAP to use root entity dc=atlassian,dc=pl):
parent_group.ldif

version: 1

dn: cn=parent_group,dc=atlassian,dc=pl
objectClass: groupOfUniqueNames
cn: parent_group
uniqueMember: cn=sub_group,dc=atlassian,dc=pl
description: Parent group

sub_group.ldif

version: 1

dn: cn=sub_group,dc=atlassian,dc=pl
objectClass: groupOfUniqueNames
cn: sub_group
uniqueMember: 
description: Child group

Also to see effect of exception which you should get in step 6 you may add user and set membership using uniqueMember attribute - this user won't be added to any group because of synchronization fail (user should be created, groups also, but no user membership in group will be created).

This can also be reproduced without the use of nested groups.
fields.summary: Directory synchronisation fails when the name of a group changes in case

fields.description:
This is related to CWD-3692 .

Crowd has database lockups under significant load.  It appears to be related to locking of the cwd_token table by an insert or delete statement.  Crowd appears to use up its database connections and thus become unresponsive. I have updated that ticket with comments which document the queries in question that hang:

https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CWD-3692?focusedCommentId=561387&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-561387
fields.summary: Crowd freezes under heavy load
Crowd API Should Support True Read-Only Access

fields.description:

This is fixed upstream in [BEANUTILS-379|https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEANUTILS-379], so upgrade to a version including the fix.
fields.summary: Upgrade commons-beanutils to avoid duplicate package warning

fields.description:
h2. Steps to reproduce

# Bring up Crowd using HSQLDB 2.3.0 (this may be reproducible with Postgres 8.4, to be confirmed).
# Set up Crowd to use an Embedded database.
# Continue through the setup process.

h2. Expected result

Crowd setup process completes and user is presented with a login screen.

h2. Observed result

Crowd hangs after the last screen of the setup process, and never presents the login screen. Crowd becomes unresponsive.

h2. Workaround 1
{panel}

At this point the workaround is to switch the session storage to in-memory from database storage:
 [Session Configuration|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Session+Configuration]

The in-memory storage is explained in more detail on the page linked above.

If you cannot keep crowd up long enough to access the Administration console, or crowd will simply not finish starting up, follow these steps to modify the value directly in the database:
# Shutdown crowd - ensure the pid is stopped
# Perform a database backup
# Connect to the database
# Execute this sql:
{code:sql}update cwd_property 
set property_value='false'
where property_name='database.token.storage.enabled';{code}
# 
# Restart Crowd
# Validate the session storage is now in-memory by Navigating to Administration > Session Config
{panel}

h2. Workaround 2
{panel}
(!) If workaround 1 does not help, you may try this. However, please note that performing this workaround will force users to login again.

# Shutdown crowd - ensure the pid is stopped
# Perform a database backup
# Connect to the database
# Execute this sql:
{code:sql}delete from cwd_token;{code}
# Restart Crowd
# Validate the session storage is now in-memory by Navigating to Administration > Session Config
{panel}
fields.summary: Adding a token to database causes transaction to lock indefinitely

fields.description:
h2. Symptoms

Crowd becomes unresponsive. A thread dump shows that all threads are in  WAITING state, except one which is RUNNABLE and reading from the JDBC socket ({{SocketInputStream.read}}) while at the same time holding the WRITE lock in {{SwitchableTokenManagerImpl}}.

Postgres logs contain "LOG:  could not send data to client: Broken pipe".

h2. Steps to reproduce

This issue is affecting some customers. I haven't been able to reproduce it locally. The key to reproduce this issue seems to be able to kill a connection between Crowd and Postgres in such way that Postgres believes it's closed ("broken pipe"), while Crowd keeps waiting to read from the socket.

This issue seems to happen only when using database token storage.
fields.summary: A failure in a single DB connection causes deadlock in Crowd

fields.description:
Since we switched to a threaded MPM for Apache we started to notice SEGFAULTED children on the instances.
Is the code for authnz_crowd_module and authz_svn_crowd_module fully reentrant and thread-safe?
fields.summary: Are Apache crowd authorization modules thread-safe?

fields.description:
As a customer I want to be able to map AD/LADP groups to crowd with all members (including people that are members of a sub-groups) but without creating the huge list of nested sub-groups. 

-- I would call this flattening of the group membership

By using LDAP/AD filtering we can limit which groups are to be mapped inside Crowd but we also want to put all members inside this groups without having to create tons of sub-groups.

Lets say we have "Support" that contains "Americas Support", "EMEA Support", some users and some other groups. "EMEA Support" can also have groups with each country or city and so on..

Obviously, as a customer we want to be sure that the "Support" group inside Crowd does contain all people from all sub-groups. 

I would even go so far to propose this to be the default behavior. 

When you send and email to a mailing list, this will reach all people even if they are not direct-members. Still, on crowd this happens only when you import all the nested memberships, and this sucks because it does SPAM the list of groups (a lot!)

As an implementation idea, you could import subgroups as "disabled" groups unless someone is manually activate them.

Also, another concern for me is, the lack of flattening support could prevent us from using Crowd with systems that are not supporting the nested group behavior.
fields.summary: Nested group import should allow flattening groups from AD/LDAP

fields.description:
h3. Diagnosis
Group names have had their case changed in the source directory. The following will appear in the atlassian-crowd.log:
{code}
2013-09-12 01:44:15,408 WARN [scheduler_Worker-9] [atlassian.crowd.directory.DbCachingRemoteChangeOperations] findGroupsToUpdate remote group name [ group1 ] casing differs from local group name [ GROUP1 ]. Group details will be kept updated, but the group name cannot be updated
{code}

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Set up Crowd 2.7 and Confluence 5.4.1 (these are the versions I used, but this bug has been apparent since at least Confluence 5.3.1, JIRA 6.1.2 and Stash 2.11.2)
# Create a Crowd user 
# Create a group called 'group1'
# Add the user to the group
# Create a group in Crowd called confluence-administrators and add the user to it
# Set up Crowd as a directory in Confluence (or JIRA) and sync it
# Change the name of the group in tthe Confluence (or JIRA) database to 'GROUP1' and sync again
(This is to simulate the casing being changed in an external directory, eg AD. You cannot change the case directly in Crowd, but if AD is connected to Crowd and Crowd is connected to Confluence, when the casing changes in AD this issue occurs)
# Log in to Confluence as the user. 
# Go to Admin > Users in Confluence (confirm the password when prompted)
# View your group memberships and confirm you are a member of GROUP1
# Go to the Dashboard
# Click in the top banner to drop admin rights 
# Go back to Admin > Users, confirming password again when prompted
# Confirm that you are no longer a member of GROUP1
# Repeat steps 11 - 13 and confirm that you are a member of GROUP1 again
# Repeat again and confirm the membership is gone

NB: This is similar to old issues that used to occur when the casing changed, but they all occurred on intermittent directory syncs. That does not appear to be occurring anymore, and it is now only authenticating into the admin section of both JIRA and Confluence that causes this issue.
fields.summary: Changing groupname casing causes intermittent loss of group membership in Confluence and JIRA

fields.description:
We sync our users from LDAP, and recently had a user that couldn't log in using the character "ç" in his password. When we've changed the password to something different, it worked.

I'm not sure if this is a bug or by design? We've seen the same behavior in Confluence as well.

If this is by design, is there a list of (un)supported characters for passwords? Since we use LDAP for most of our services, this is quite annoying.
fields.summary: JIRA password does not support "ç"

fields.description: From attached support cases, it seems that when JIRA is used as Crowd Server in front of an AD, the user rename can fail during the incremental sync and leave the Crowd database in a bad state, with EXTERNAL_ID duplication. This may be related to some problem happening during the synchronization (JIRA went down?). In any case, this should be investigated as a potential bug.
fields.summary: User rename does not work correctly in JIRA User Server mode

fields.description:
Right know, when an update operation in a cached directory fails because the cache was in an inconsistent state, sometimes the cache consistency is locally restored, and sometimes it is not.

For instance, if a group is removed in a Crowd cached LDAP directory, but someone was faster and independently removed the group from the remote LDAP server, Crowd will immediately remove the group from the cache. The result is that the cache is left in a consistent state with respect to the remote LDAP server (the group does not exist in any of them).

However, if a group is added in a Crowd cached LDAP directory, but someone was faster and independently added the group to the remote LDAP server, Crowd will not add the group to the cache. The result is that the cache remains in a temporarily inconsistent state with respect to the remote LDAP server (the group exists in the LDAP server, but not yet in the cache). This situation fixes itself in the next sync, but until then, a call to "find group" will not find the group.
fields.summary: Improve partial cache consistency of cached directories after failed update operations

fields.description:
It would be very helpful to have option to configure maximum attempt of failed login and a mechanism to lock/disable user account after the maximum failed attempt is reached.
Decide upon the number of login attempts to be allowed (configurable), and make sure that the account will be locked once the permitted number of attempts is exceeded. To avoid unnecessary support calls from genuine users who were locked out of their account and require enabling, it is possible to suspend account activity only temporarily, and enable it after a specific period of time. Locking the account for a period of ten minutes or so is usually sufficient to block brute force attacks.
This would be a huge benefit for Crowd to have as implementation.
fields.summary: Provide the option to temporarily lock a user account after the maximum configured login attempts

fields.description:
Currently, the confluence picker does not sanitize the input ( <crowd-url>/crowd/console/secure/pickers/displayPicker.action). 

Proof of concept.

fields.summary: Cross Site Scripting vulnerabilities in Pickers
Using getGroup followed by addGroup followed by getGroup does not work as expected.

fields.description:
Assume you have a 50 user license and 40 active users.

When you import a CSV file with 11 users...

* You have no chance to get the 90%-warning-email in time
* Everything works fine, until Crowd recalculates the users again (which may take hours)
* After that, you're pretty much screwed since no application is able to authenticate its users any longer.

We've been screwed two times so far.

I think a warning during an import, that one's going to exceed the license limit with such an import, would by a very quick win.
fields.summary: Check import against License Limit
